ANU.name: Thomas Nulley Valdes
ANU.colleges: College of Arts and Social Sciences
interest: 19th, 20th, and 21st Century Latin American fiction; World Literature theories and methodologies; Latin America's historical identity discourse; anthologies; Latino literature in the USA; Chilean literary history.
ANU.biography: During his PhD candidature he conducted fieldwork research for the purposes of acquiring archival material and in order to conduct in-person interviews with authors in Chile, The United States, Portugal, and Spain. Some of these interviews have been published in Latin American Literature Today, Nagarí, Letra Urbana and also in the edited book McCrack: McOndo y el Crack y los destinos de la literatura latinoamericana. He have presented research papers at congresses and university seminars at The University of New South Wales, Sydney University, Griffith University, La Trobe University, the 47th NeMLA Annual Convention, The Humanities Research Centre, Macquarie University, Indiana University, The Australian National University, and the Association of Iberian and Latin American Studies of Australasia Conventions in 2018 and 2020. His peer-reviewed research has appeared in edited collections as well as in Journal of Iberian and Latin American Research and 1616: Anuario de literatura comparada.
project: Thomas completed his doctoral thesis on the contemporary Latin American short story anthology McOndo (1996), approaching the text from the theoretical frameworks and methodologies world literature theory, especially Pascale Casanova's, in order to give greater coherence to this anthology as well as inform and develop Casanova's theory and methodology when used with contemporary literature and in complex literary spaces such as the Latin American field.
